H0.text: Chromosomes are the genetic structures that are not homologous and cannot pair during meiosis, which is why most hybrids are sterile.

H1.text: Zygotes are the genetic structures that are not homologous and cannot pair during meiosis, which is why most hybrids are sterile.

H2.text: Ribosomes are the genetic structures that are not homologous and cannot pair during meiosis, which is why most hybrids are sterile.

H3.text: Phenotypes are the genetic structures that are not homologous and cannot pair during meiosis, causing most hybrids to be sterile.

A4.text: Chromosomes can also be fused artificially. For example, when the 16 chromosomes of yeast were fused into one giant chromosome, it was found that the cells were still viable with only somewhat reduced growth rates.

A5.text: Some chromosome abnormalities do not cause disease in carriers, such as translocations, or chromosomal inversions, although they may lead to a higher chance of bearing a child with a chromosome disorder.

A6.text: Hybrid sterility is due to the interaction between the genes of the two species involved; to chromosomal imbalances due to the different number of chromosomes in the parent species; or to nucleusâ€‘cytoplasmic interactions such as in the case of Culex described above.

A7.text: The sperm of the hybrid male do not survive in the semen receptors of the females.

A8.text: homologous chromosomes pair with each other and undergo genetic recombination

A9.text: crossovers create physical links known as chiasmata between the homologous chromosomes

A10.text: During meiosis, genetic recombination (by random segregation) and crossing over produces daughter cells that each contain different combinations of maternally and paternally coded genes.

A11.text: Homologous chromosomes are made up of chromosome pairs of approximately the same length, centromere position, and staining pattern, for genes with the same corresponding loci.

A12.text: Mules, hinnies, and other normally sterile interspecific hybrids cannot produce viable gametes, because differences in chromosome structure prevent appropriate pairing and segregation during meiosis, meiosis is disrupted, and viable sperm and eggs are not formed.

A13.text: Chromosome duplication allows orderly meiosis and so viable seed can be produced.

A15.text: Creation of new species through hybridization was thought to be common only in plants, and rare in animals.

A16.text: Chromosomal crossover involves recombination between the paired chromosomes inherited from each of one's parents, generally occurring during meiosis.

A17.text: Nevertheless, this mutant gave rise to spore viability patterns suggesting that segregation of non-exchange chromosomes occurred efficiently. Thus in S. cerevisiae proper segregation apparently does not entirely depend on crossovers between homologous pairs.

A18.text: During crossover, chromosomes exchange stretches of DNA, effectively shuffling the gene alleles between the chromosomes.

A19.text: The probability of chromosomal crossover occurring between two given points on the chromosome is related to the distance between the points.

A20.text: a diploid somatic cell has two sets of homologous chromosomes, one of which is a copy of the chromosome set from the sperm and one a copy of the chromosome set from the egg cell.

A21.text: During fertilization, a spermatozoon and an ovum, each carrying half of the genetic information of an individual, unite to form a zygote that develops into a new diploid organism.
